articles.headline: David Greenglass, the Brother Who Doomed Ethel Rosenberg, Dies at 92
articles.snippet: Mr. Greenglass, whose testimony against his sister and brother-in-law, Ethel and Julius Rosenberg, in a 1951 spy trial helped send them to the electric chair, later admitted to lying.
articles.abstract: Mr. Greenglass, whose testimony against his sister and brother-in-law, Ethel and Julius Rosenberg, in a 1951 spy trial helped send them to the electric chair, later admitted to lying.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was the most notorious spy case of the Cold War — the conviction and execution of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg for passing atomic secrets to the Soviet Union — and it rested largely on the testimony of Ms. Rosenberg’s brother David Greenglass, whose name to many became synonymous with betrayal.

articles.headline: Spain Exposes Holes in Plans to Treat Ebola
articles.snippet: Madrid, where a nurse contracted the disease, mostly dismantled its infectious disease center as part of a government cost-cutting plan.
articles.abstract: Madrid, where a nurse contracted the disease, mostly dismantled its infectious disease center as part of a government cost-cutting plan.
articles.lead_paragraph: MADRID — The scene conveyed a First World precision: A 75-year-old Spanish priest, stricken with Ebola in Liberia, arrived in Madrid on a special military jet. A helicopter buzzed overhead as ambulances transported him for treatment. Expressing confidence in the preparations, a Spanish health official said the risk of the virus’s spreading was “virtually nil.”

articles.headline: Supreme Court Allows Texas Abortion Clinics to Stay Open
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court blocked a federal appeals court ruling that was forcing abortion clinics in Texas to close, allowing them to remain open during appeals.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court blocked a federal appeals court ruling that was forcing abortion clinics in Texas to close, allowing them to remain open during appeals.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday allowed more than a dozen Texas abortion clinics to reopen, blocking a state law that had imposed strict requirements on abortion providers. Had the law been allowed to stand, it would have caused all but eight of the state’s abortion clinics to close and would have required many women to travel more than 150 miles to the nearest abortion provider.

articles.headline: The Risks of Cheap Water
articles.snippet: Higher prices are essential to induce conservation and investment in water-saving technology and to steer water to where it is valued most.
articles.abstract: Higher prices are essential to induce conservation and investment in water-saving technology and to steer water to where it is valued most.
articles.lead_paragraph: This summer, California’s water authority declared that wasting water — hosing a sidewalk, for example — was a crime. Next door, in Nevada, Las Vegas has paid out $200 million over the last decade for homes and businesses to pull out their lawns.

articles.headline: Fed Is Silent on Doomsday Book, a Blueprint for Fighting Crises
articles.snippet: The Doomsday Book is a collection of legal opinions on the Fed’s authority to fight financial crises. And that’s all the New York Fed has to say.
articles.abstract: The Doomsday Book is a collection of legal opinions on the Fed’s authority to fight financial crises. And that’s all the New York Fed has to say.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It’s called the Doomsday Book — though by now, officials at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York probably regret they ever came up with that catchy nickname.

articles.headline: C.I.A. Study of Covert Aid Fueled Skepticism About Helping Syrian Rebels
articles.snippet: A classified review concluded that many past attempts by the agency to arm foreign forces covertly had a minimal impact on the long-term outcome of a conflict.
articles.abstract: A classified review concluded that many past attempts by the agency to arm foreign forces covertly had a minimal impact on the long-term outcome of a conflict.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Central Intelligence Agency has run guns to insurgencies across the world during its 67-year history — from Angola to Nicaragua to Cuba. The continuing C.I.A. effort to train Syrian rebels is just the latest example of an American president becoming enticed by the prospect of using the spy agency to covertly arm and train rebel groups.

articles.headline: With New Ebola Case Confirmed, U.S. Vows Vigilance
articles.snippet: The news that a second nurse was infected in Dallas and that she was cleared to fly the day before showing symptoms raised questions about officials’ ability to control the disease.
articles.abstract: The news that a second nurse was infected in Dallas and that she was cleared to fly the day before showing symptoms raised questions about officials’ ability to control the disease.
articles.lead_paragraph: DALLAS — New shortcomings emerged Wednesday in the nation’s response to the Ebola virus after it was revealed that a second nurse was infected with Ebola at a hospital here and that she had traveled on a commercial flight the day before she showed symptoms of the disease.
articles.byline: By Manny Fernandez and Jack Healy

articles.headline: HBO Plans New Streaming Service, With Eye on Cord Cutters
articles.snippet: The premium network is launching a stand-alone service in an attempt to lure a new generation of viewers who might have canceled their cable service.
articles.abstract: The premium network is launching a stand-alone service in an attempt to lure a new generation of viewers who might have canceled their cable service.
articles.lead_paragraph: HBO announced Wednesday that it would start a stand-alone Internet streaming service in the United States in 2015 that would not require a subscription to a traditional television service, a move that intensifies the premium cable network’s growing rivalry with Netflix.

articles.headline: Samsung’s Superior Note 4 Smartphone Gives Glimpse of Computing’s Future
articles.snippet: With a half dozen new features that will delight users, Samsung’s latest smartphone may have its owners forgetting about all their other computers.
articles.abstract: With a half dozen new features that will delight users, Samsung’s latest smartphone may have its owners forgetting about all their other computers.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2011 Samsung unveiled a smartphone so big it looked as if it must have been a joke, a mistake or a turn toward conceptual art.

articles.headline: Feminist Critics of Video Games Facing Threats in ‘GamerGate’ Campaign
articles.snippet: The atmosphere has become so toxic that critics and developers are urging big companies in the $70-billion-a-year video game industry to do more to stop it.
articles.abstract: The atmosphere has become so toxic that critics and developers are urging big companies in the $70-billion-a-year video game industry to do more to stop it.
articles.lead_paragraph: Anita Sarkeesian, a feminist cultural critic, has for months received death and rape threats from opponents of her recent work challenging the stereotypes of women in video games. Bomb threats for her public talks are now routine. One detractor created a game in which players can click their mouse to punch an image of her face.
